docs.title: limnd2 package
docs.text:
Warning

This Python package is not yet available for the public, both the package and the documentation is still being worked on.

.nd2 (Nikon NIS Elements) file reader and writer in Python.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
PyPIManual (Windows)Manual (Linux)

Warning

This Python package is not released on PyPI yet, use manual installation.

You can install this package from PyPI by running following command:

pip install limnd2

Run following commands in a folder where you want to install this package.

git clone https://github.com/Laboratory-Imaging/limnd2.git
cd limnd2
python -m venv env
env\Scripts\activate
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -r requirements.txt

Run following commands in a folder where you want to install this package.

git clone https://github.com/Laboratory-Imaging/limnd2.git
cd limnd2
python3 -m venv env
source env/bin/activate
python3 -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Reading .nd2 files
docs.text: An example Python file showcasing how to read an .nd2 file with this library is found at GitHub repo for this page: example_reader.py.

docs.title: Opening .nd2 file
docs.text:
An .nd2 file can be opened using Nd2Reader class like this:

nd2 = limnd2.Nd2Reader("file.nd2")

However it is recommended to open .nd2 files (especially when writing) using with statement to automatically close the file.

example_reader.py
with limnd2.Nd2Reader("file.nd2") as nd2:

docs.title: Getting summary information
docs.text:
Quick access to information about the file can be gained with generalImageInfo dictionary:

example_reader.py
print("Summary information")
for key, value in nd2.generalImageInfo.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")
See example output 
Summary information
filename: file.nd2
path: C:\Users\user\Desktop\nd2_files
bit_depth: 32bit float
loops: XY(25), Z(5)
dimension: 1024 x 1024 (2 comps 32bit float) x 125 frames: XY(25), Z(5)
file_size: 6732537856
frame_res: 1024 x 1024
volume_size: 40MB
sizes: 6GB on disk, 8MB frame, 40MB volume
calibration: 0.432 µm/px
mtime: 06/07/21 14:17:56
app_created: NIS-Elements AR 5.20.00 (Build 1423)

docs.title: Getting text information
docs.text:
More information about components can be in imageTextInfo dataclass, though this information is stored as a string:

example_reader.py
print("More information")
for key, value in nd2.imageTextInfo.to_dict().items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")
See example output 
More information

docs.title: Getting image attributes
docs.text:
Image attributes dataclass mostly contains information about dimensions of an image like width and height, number of components and number of frames in nd2 file.

For all properties and methods of this dataclass see attributes.py.

To get image attributes use imageAttributes attribute of Nd2Reader instance created in previous step.

example_reader.py
attributes = nd2.imageAttributes

Then you can use following properties to get information about the file:

example_reader.py
print(f"Image resolution: {attributes.width} x {attributes.height}")
print(f"Number of components: {attributes.componentCount}")
print(f"Number of frames: {attributes.frameCount}")
print(f"Image size (in bytes): {attributes.imageBytes}")
print(f"Python data type: {attributes.dtype}")
See example output 
Image resolution: 1024 x 1024
Number of components: 2
Number of frames: 125
Image size (in bytes): 8388608
Python data type: <class 'numpy.float32'>

docs.title: Getting image data
docs.text:
This library uses NumPy arrays to store image data found in the .nd2 file, if you want to access image data itself, you can do so by using .image() method with index of the image you want to get like this:

example_reader.py
image = nd2.image(0)        # get first image
print(type(image))
print("Numpy array shape:", image.shape, "stored datatype:", image.dtype)
See example output 
<class 'numpy.ndarray'>
Numpy array shape: (1024, 1024, 2) stored datatype: float32

If you want to get all images in the .nd2 file, use a for loop with frameCount property from image attributes.

example_reader.py
images = []
for i in range(attributes.frameCount):
    images.append(nd2.image(i))
print(f"Obtained {len(images)} frames.")
See example output 
Obtained 125 frames.

docs.title: Getting experiment data
docs.text:
Experiments in .nd2 files define how image sequences are organized and looped. The most common types of loops include:

  • Time Loop (timeloop): A sequence of images captured over time.
  • Z-Stack (zstack): Frames stacked along the z-axis, representing different focal planes.
  • Multi-Point (multipoint): Images captured at multiple specified locations (points) with known coordinates.

An image can have no experiment, a single experiment, or a combination of multiple experiments.

To obtain data structure with information about used experiments, use experiment property.

example_reader.py
experiment = nd2.experiment

Then to see what kind of experiment .nd2 file contains, you can iterate over this data structure with a for loop:

example_reader.py
print("Experiment loops in image:")
for e in experiment:
    print(f"Experiment name: {e.name}, number of frames: {e.count}")
See example output 
Experiment loops in image:
Experiment name: Multipoint, number of frames: 25
Experiment name: Z-Stack, number of frames: 5

Now if we want to access attributes and methods for specific loop type, we can use .findLevel() method with ExperimentLoopType type as parameter, in this example we search for Z-Stack experiment = use value ExperimentLoopType.eEtZStackLoop.

Then we can access data for this experiment through parameters of this experiment, in this example we use attributes and properties of ExperimentZStackLoop.

example_reader.py
zstack = experiment.findLevel(limnd2.ExperimentLoopType.eEtZStackLoop)

print("Distance between frames:", zstack.uLoopPars.dZStep, "μm")
print("Home index:", zstack.uLoopPars.homeIndex)
print("Top position:", zstack.uLoopPars.top, "μm")
print("Bottom position:", zstack.uLoopPars.bottom, "μm")
See example output 
Distance between frames: 4.0 μm
Home index: 2
Top position: 5.0 μm
Bottom position: -5.0 μm

For all attributes of all experiments type look into experiment.py

docs.title: Getting metadata
docs.text:
Metadata in .nd2 file contain a lot of additional data about the image, especially about planes, this information includes:

  • plane name
  • modality
  • filter path
  • sample settings
  • fluorescent probe
  • much more, see metadata.py for full information about .nd2 metadata

To get metadata, use pictureMetadata attribute like this:

example_reader.py
metadata = nd2.pictureMetadata

To iterate over planes in the image, you can use .channels() method from the metadata that just were created, then .sampleSettings() method to get sample settings for given plane.

With channel and settings stored in separate variables, you can then access selected attributes like this:

example_reader.py
for channel in metadata.channels:
    settings = metadata.sampleSettings(channel)
    print("Channel name:", channel.sDescription)
    print(" Modality:", " ".join(limnd2.metadata.PicturePlaneModalityFlags.to_str_list(channel.uiModalityMask)))
    print(" Emission wavelength:", channel.emissionWavelengthNm)
    print(" Excitation wavelength:", channel.excitationWavelengthNm)

    print(" Camera name", settings.cameraName)
    print(" Microscope name", settings.microscopeName)
    print(" Objective magnification", settings.objectiveMagnification)
    print()
See example output 
Channel name: DETECTOR A
 Modality: Camera AUX
 Emission wavelength: 520.0
 Excitation wavelength: 488.0
 Camera name Nikon A1 LFOV
 Microscope name Ti2 Microscope
 Objective magnification 40.0

Channel name: DETECTOR B
 Modality: Camera AUX
 Emission wavelength: 650.0
 Excitation wavelength: 488.0
 Camera name Nikon A1 LFOV
 Microscope name Ti2 Microscope
 Objective magnification 40.0

docs.title: Getting other data
docs.text:
Attributes, experiments, metadata, and image data are the most important parts of an .nd2 file, which is why they were the focus of this guide. The limnd2 module can also access information about binary layers, ROIs, and other data stored in the file. However, at this time, we do not provide a guide on how to read these additional components.

If this causes any issues or you need further clarification, please feel free to head over to the Discussion page on our GitHub repository and let us know.

docs.title: Full API reference
docs.text:
Here are the most important files in this library and an overview of what they contain:

  • nd2.py - contains classes for opening ND2 files for reading and writing
  • attributes.py - contains data structures about image attributes (width, height, component count, sequence count, ...)
  • experiment.py - contains data structures about experiment loops (timeloop, z-stack, multipoint, ...)
    • experiment_factory.py - contains helpers for creating experiment data structure
  • metadata.py - contains data structures about image attributes (width, height, component count, sequence count, ...)

Compatibility layer:

  • nd2file.py - serves as a wrapper around limnd2 library to provide same interface to nd2 library by Talley Lambert

docs.title: Feedback
docs.text: Did you find a bug? Do you have a question about this package or an idea for improvement? Join the discussion here.

docs.title: ImageAttributes dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: LVSerializable

Dataclass for ND2 Image attributes chunk, stores mostly information about image width, height, number of components and bit depth of each pixel, as well as information about compression and total number of images.

docs.title: componentBytes property
docs.text:
componentBytes: int

Size of component in bytes.

docs.title: componentCount property
docs.text:
componentCount: int

Returns number of components in the image.

docs.title: dtype property
docs.text:
dtype: NumpyDTypeLike

Returns numpy datatype used for storing image data in Python.

docs.title: frameCount property
docs.text:
frameCount: int

Returns number of frames in the ND2 file.

docs.title: height property
docs.text:
height: int

Returns height of the image in pixels.

docs.title: imageBytes property
docs.text:
imageBytes: int

Total size of the image in bytes.

docs.title: lowerPowSizeList property
docs.text:
lowerPowSizeList: list[int]

Returns list of powers of 2 between ND2_MIN_DOWNSAMPLED_SIZE and image resolution.

docs.title: pixelBytes property
docs.text:
pixelBytes: int

Size of pixel in bytes.

docs.title: powSize property
docs.text:
powSize: int

Returns next power of 2 for bigger dimension.

docs.title: powSizeBase property
docs.text:
powSizeBase: int

Returns exponent used in powSize() function.

docs.title: safe_dtype property
docs.text:
safe_dtype: NumpyDTypeLike

Returns numpy datatype that will always be big enough to fit pixel component data.

docs.title: shape property
docs.text:
shape: tuple[int, int, int]

Returns shape of the image which can be used with in array (height_pixels, width_pixels, component_count)

docs.title: strides property
docs.text:
strides: tuple[int, int, int]

Returns the strides of the image which can be used in numpy array

docs.title: width property
docs.text:
width: int

Returns width of the image in pixels.

docs.title: widthBytes property
docs.text:
widthBytes: int

Size of image row in bytes.

docs.title: calcWidthBytes staticmethod
docs.text:
calcWidthBytes(width: int, bits: int, comps: int) -> int

Calculates number of bytes per single image row.

docs.title: create staticmethod
docs.text:
create(width: int, height: int, component_count: int, bits: int, sequence_count: int) -> ImageAttributes

Warning

This function is used for creating new ImageAttributes instance, usually for creating new .nd2 files with Nd2Writer class.

Create ImageAttributes instance from simplified parameters:

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default width int

width in pixels

required height int

height in pixels

required component_count int

number of components

required bits int

number of bits per pixel component

required sequence_count int

total number of frames in ND2 file (product of size of each dimension)

required

Decodes ImageAttributes from ND2 lite variant chunk.

docs.text: This file is for experiments

Experiment Level

Enum specifiying which experiment type was used in ExperimentLevel

Name Type Description eEtTimeLoop int

Timeloop experiment

eEtXYPosLoop int

Multipoint experiment

eEtZStackLoop int

Z-stack experiment

docs.title: Experiment factory module
docs.text:
This module contains helper classes and functions for creating ExperimentLevel instances using simplified parameters for each experiment type. Those instances should be used with Nd2Writer instance for altering / creating .nd2 files.

Warning

Since this module is used to creating experiment data structures, you should not use any part of this module if you only read an .nd2 file.

docs.title: MExp
docs.text: Data structure for creating multipoint experiment using list of x and y coordinates.

docs.title: __init__
docs.text:
__init__(frame_count: int, xcoords: list[float] = None, ycoords: list[float] = None)

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default frame_count int

number of frames in the experiment loop

required xcoords list[float] = None

list of x coordinates

None ycoords list[float] = None

list of y coordinates

None

Raises:

Type Description ValueError

if lengths of coordinate lists are not equal to frame_count.

docs.title: create_experiment
docs.text:
create_experiment(*args: Exp) -> ExperimentLevel

This function chains and nests several simplified experiments into single ExperimentLevel instance.

Warning

This function chains experiments without any consideration for their validity or order, experiments should follow timeloop, multipoint, z-stack order and each experiment type should be used at most once, however this function does not enforce any of this.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default *args Exp

list of simplified experiments to chain

()

docs.title: ChannelSettings dataclass
docs.text:
Warning

This function is used for creating new PictureMetadata instance, usually for creating new .nd2 files with Nd2Writer class. Do not use this class if you simply read existing .nd2 file.

Represents simplified settings for an image channel.

Attributes:

Name Type Description name str

The name of the channel.

modality str | PicturePlaneModality | PicturePlaneModalityFlags

The modality of the channel either as a string (e.g., fluorescence, brightfield) or as instance of PicturePlaneModality or PicturePlaneModalityFlags

excitation_wavelength int

The excitation wavelength in nanometers.

emission_wavelength int

The emission wavelength in nanometers.

color str

The color representation of the channel (e.g., "red", "blue", or hex code).

microscope MicroscopeSettings | None

MicroscopeSettings for given channel.

docs.title: convert
docs.text:
convert(index) -> tuple[PicturePlaneDesc, SampleSettings]

Converts channel settings to instance of PicturePlaneDesc and SampleSettings returned as a tuple.

Returns:

Type Description tuple[PicturePlaneDesc, SampleSettings]

Created plane description and corresponsing sample settings.

docs.title: modality_flags
docs.text:
modality_flags() -> PicturePlaneModalityFlags

Converts provided modality to instance of PicturePlaneModalityFlags, which is stored in nd2 file. Do not use this class if you simply read existing .nd2 file.

Returns:

Type Description PicturePlaneModalityFlags

PicturePlaneModalityFlags instance with modality.

docs.title: MicroscopeSettings dataclass
docs.text:
Warning

This function is used for creating new PictureMetadata instance, usually for creating new .nd2 files with Nd2Writer class. Do not use this class if you simply read existing .nd2 file.

Represents simplifies settings for a microscope, not used for reading ND2 file.

Attributes:

Name Type Description objective_magnification float

The magnification power of the microscope's objective lens.

objective_numerical_aperture float

The numerical aperture of the objective lens.

zoom_magnification float

The zoom magnification factor.

immersion_refractive_index float

The refractive index of the immersion medium.

pinhole_diameter float

The diameter of the pinhole in micrometers.

camera_name str

Name of the camera used.

microscope_name str

Name of the microscope used.

docs.title: PictureMetadataPicturePlanes dataclass
docs.text: Bases: LVSerializable

docs.title: valid property
docs.text:
valid: bool

Checks if PictureMetadataPicturePlanes insance has valid number of channels.

Returns:

Type Description bool

True if number of channels is valid, False otherwise.

docs.title: makeValid
docs.text:
makeValid(comps: int, **kwargs) -> None

Attempts to fix info about channels using specified number of channels.

This function creates channel info basec on component count like this:

comps = 1: function creates one Mono channel

comps = 2: function creates channels Channel_1, Channel_2

comps = 3: function creates one RGB channel

comps >= 4: function creates channels Channel_1 ... Channel_N

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default comps int

The number of components in the image.

required **kwargs dict

Additional parameters to pass to each plane.

{}

docs.title: create_metadata
docs.text:
create_metadata(channels: list[ChannelSettings], pixel_calibration: float = 0.0, microscope: MicroscopeSettings = None) -> PictureMetadata

Warning

This function is used for creating new PictureMetadata instance, usually for creating new .nd2 files with Nd2Writer class.

Creates PictureMetadata instance from simplified information about channels and microscope, not used for reading ND2 file.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default channels list[ChannelSettings]

List of ChannelSetting instances, which contain channel names, modality, wavelength info and color.

required pixel_calibration float = 0.0

Size of one pixel in micrometers

0.0 microscope MicroscopeSettings

MicroscopeSettings for ALL channels (overwrites MicroscopeSettings stored in each channel).

None

Returns:

Type Description PictureMetadata

PictureMetadata instance with channel and microsope information.

docs.title: Nd2Reader
docs.text: Class for reading ND2 files and its attributes, metadata, properties, image data and so on.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Create Nd2 reader instance like this (use with statement to automatically close a file).

import limnd2
with limnd2.Nd2Reader('file.nd2') as nd2:
    attributes = nd2.imageAttributes       # to get image attributes, see ImageAttributes class
    experiment = nd2.experiment            # to get experiments in an image, see ExperimentLevel class
    metadata = nd2.pictureMetadata         # to get image metadata, see PictureMetadata class


    print(f"Image resolution: {attributes.width} x {attributes.height}, # of components: {attributes.componentCount}")

    for i in range(attributes.componentCount):
        image = nd2.image(i)                            # get image with given sequence index

image(seqindex: int) -> NumpyArrayLike

Get image data from specified frame as NumPy array.

Parameters:

seqindex: int Image sequence index you want to get.

docs.title: Nd2Writer
docs.text:
Experimental ND2 file writer.

Supports encoding od all image attributes, most commonly used experiments and most of image metadata. Currently does not support encoding of Wellplates, binary layers, ROIs and any custom data and text into chunk.

Python dataclasses encodeable by this writer inherit from LVSerializable class, in those classes attributes stored with UNKNOWN, ENCODING_NOT_IMPLEMENTED and DO_NOT_ENCODE enum will not be encoded.

docs.title: __init__
docs.text:

Either opens existing .nd2 file for writing (adding or overwriting) chunks or creates an empty .nd2 file.

Parameters:

Filename of the ND2 file.

docs.title: Nd2File
docs.text: This file serves as compatibility layer between this limnd2 library maintained by Laboratory Imaging s.r.o. (https://github.com/Laboratory-Imaging/limnd2) and nd2 library maintained by Talley Lambert (https://github.com/tlambert03/nd2) It copies the interface of nd2 library, but uses limnd2 library on the "backend", essentially making a wrapper around it.
